questions.text: A 47-year-old man presents with complaints of clumsiness and inability to distinguish objects by touch when he reaches into his pocket. Neurologic examination reveals preserved temperature and pain sensation but impaired two-point discrimination and poor tactile localisation on the right side. A lesion in which of the following spinal cord tracts is most likely responsible for this deficit?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Loss of tactile discrimination with preserved pain and temperature suggests dorsal column dysfunction.

Dorsal Column-Medial Lemniscus Pathway:

  • The DCML pathway transmits:
    • Fine touch
    • Two-point discrimination
    • Tactile localization
    • Vibration
    • Conscious proprioception
  • Stereognosis requires integration of DCML input in the somatosensory association cortex (areas 5, 7), which is impaired with DCML lesions.
  • Preservation of pain and temperature implies that the anterolateral system (spinothalamic tracts) is intact.
  • Explanation of other options:
  • Anterior spinothalamic tract (Option A): carries crude touch, not fine discrimination.
  • Lateral spinothalamic tract (Option C):  transmits pain and temperature.
  • Corticospinal tract (Option D): carries motor signals; does not mediate sensory function.
  • Key Takeaway:
  • The DCML pathway is essential for high-resolution tactile perception and stereognosis; its lesion spares pain and crude touch but impairs spatial and texture-based tactile processing.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male presents with chronic generalised pruritus, severely affecting his quality of life. He describes the sensation as non-painful but extremely irritating, worsened at night. He has no skin lesions. The examination is unremarkable. The physician explains that the itch sensation is transmitted through a primitive pathway that also shares fibres with pain. Which of the following agents relieves pruritus by blocking peripheral chemical mediators rather than altering neural transmission?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cetirizine is an H1 receptor antagonist that reduces pruritus by blocking histamine-mediated activation of peripheral sensory nerve endings.

  • Pruritus (itch) is transmitted via C-fibres through the anterior (ventral) spinothalamic tract, which also carries crude touch.
  • Itch is chemically mediated, mainly by:
    • Histamine → acts on H1 receptors
    • Bradykinin → acts on B2 receptors
  • Cetirizine, a second-generation H1 blocker, decreases the peripheral activation of sensory neurons and thereby reduces itch sensation.

Explanation of other options:

Calamine lotion (Option A): provides symptomatic relief through cooling and counter-stimulation (gate control theory), not by blocking chemical mediators like histamine.

Gabapentin (Option B): Alters central neural transmission by modulating calcium channels, used for neuropathic itch not mediator blockade.

Capsaicin (Option D): Depletes substance P in peripheral neurons and desensitises nociceptors, but is not specific to the histamine pathway.

Key Takeaway:

Cetirizine directly blocks histamine, a key pruritogenic mediator, and is effective in histamine-induced itching.

questions.text: A 31-year-old male presents with sensory loss in the right upper limb, including impaired vibration and fine touch. He has no motor weakness or pain. MRI reveals a right-sided posterior spinal cord compression at the cervical level. The neurologist explains that the affected tract is somatotopically organised from sacral to cervical levels in a medial-to-lateral orientation. Which of the following tracts is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fasciculus cuneatus carries sensory input from the upper body and is located lateral to the gracilis in the dorsal column.

  • The dorsal column-medial lemniscus system carries:
    • Fine touch
    • Vibration
    • Proprioception
  • Fasciculus cuneatus lies laterally in the dorsal column and carries fibres from the upper trunk and upper limbs (T6 and above).
  • The somatotopy of the dorsal column (medial to lateral) is:
    • Sacral → Lumbar → Thoracic → Cervical
  • So, compression at the lateral dorsal column in the cervical spine would affect the cuneate tract → leading to upper limb sensory loss.
  • Fasciculus cuneatuscarries cervical and thoracic fibres, which supply the upper limb. So, probably it is compressed in the above patient.

Explanation of other options:

Fasciculus gracilis (Option B) : Medially located; carries lower limb sensations (below T6).

Lateral spinothalamic tract (Option C): Carries pain and temperature, not fine touch.

Anterior spinothalamic tract (Option D): Carries crude touch, not the discriminative touch lost here.

Key Takeaway:

choices.text: The sensory signals that enter the sensory cortex, the first entry point, are layer VI
The signals from layer I project to the basal ganglia and brainstem.
Layers II receive diffuse, nonspecific input signals from lower brain centres that facilitate specific regions of the cortex.

questions.text: The cerebral cortex contains six layers extending from the surface to the deeper layer (layer I to VI). Among the following are true about these layers is/are:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Layer II of the cortex receives nonspecific ascending input from subcortical centres, helping regulate the overall excitability of local cortical areas.

  • The cortex has six layers, numbered I (outermost) to VI (deepest).
  • Layers I and II receive diffuse, nonspecific input from brainstem structures (e.g., reticular activating system), and they regulate cortical excitability.
  • Layer III (External pyramidal layer): Contains pyramidal neurons that project to other cortical areas-important for intracortical communication.
  • Layer IV is the main recipient of specific sensory input from the thalamus in the sensory cortex.
  • Layer V projects to the basal ganglia, brainstem, and spinal cord
  • Layer VI sends efferents back to the thalamus for feedback modulation.

Explanation of other options:

The sensory signals that enter the sensory cortex, the first entry point, are layer VI (Option A): Sensory signals enter primarily into Layer IV, not Layer VI.

The signals from layer I project to the basal ganglia and brainstem (Option B): Layer I is mostly acellular and does not contain efferent projections to deep structures.

Key Takeaway:

Layer II of the cerebral cortex receives nonspecific input from subcortical centres, modulating the overall excitability of cortical columns.

choices.text: Lesion of areas 5 and 7 (somatosensory association cortex)

questions.text: A 58-year-old right-handed male presents with complaints of difficulty using his left hand for daily tasks such as buttoning his shirt and handling utensils, although he retains strength and sensation. Neurological examination shows intact primary sensory and motor function, but the patient struggles with object manipulation using touch alone. MRI reveals a lesion in the superior part of the dominant parietal lobe. Which of the following best explains the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient demonstrates tactile apraxia an inability to use tactile sensory input for purposeful hand tasks despite normal strength and primary sensation. This strongly suggests involvement of the somatosensory association cortex (areas 5 and 7), located in the posterior parietal lobe.

  • These regions are responsible for:
    • Integrating touch with motor planning
    • Perceiving the spatial and contextual meaning of objects
    • Transforming sensory input into goal-directed action

Related Important Points:

  • Area 4 (Option A): Motor cortex lesion would produce weakness or paralysis not the issue here
  • Areas 3,1,2 (Option B): Lesions here cause loss of primary sensation, including astereognosis not subtle integration deficits
  • Area 6 (Option D): Premotor cortex plans motor activity but does not process tactile-spatial input

Key Takeaway:

Lesions in posterior parietal areas 5 and 7 disrupt tactile-motor integration, leading to tactile apraxia despite preserved motor and sensory pathways.

choices.text: It represents the failure of stimulus localisation due to the absence of lateral inhibition
It shows enhanced spatial resolution through lateral inhibition, sharpening the cortical response
It results from the temporal summation of action potentials at the dorsal horn
It indicates convergence of multiple tactile inputs onto the same cortical neuron

questions.text: The figure shows a cortical response to two-point tactile stimulation. One pattern demonstrates merged cortical activation, while the other shows sharply separated peaks with a central dip. Which of the following best explains the mechanism and functional outcome of the curve showing the separated peaks?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The curve with separated peaks and a dip in between reflects enhanced spatial resolution, which is achieved through lateral inhibition. This mechanism:

  • Involves inhibitory interneurons that suppress the activity of adjacent neurons
  • Enhances contrast between stimulated and non-stimulated areas
  • Is active at multiple levels: dorsal column nuclei, thalamus, and sensory cortex
  • Is essential for two-point discrimination, especially in high-resolution areas (e.g., fingertips)

When lateral inhibition is present, stimuli at two close points produce distinct peaks with minimal overlap-allowing precise localization.

Related Important Points:

  • Lateral inhibition is a universal mechanism in sensory systems (vision, touch, hearing)
  • Helps sharpen receptive fields and prevent blurring of signals
  • Damage to inhibitory circuits can reduce the ability to distinguish fine stimuli

Explanation of other options:

Failure of stimulus localisation (Option A): Refers to the blue curve with merged peaks, which occurs in the absence of lateral inhibition-not in the red curve.

Temporal summation (Option C): Involves accumulation over time, increasing overall signal strength but not improving spatial resolution.

Convergence (Option D): Refers to multiple tactile afferents synapsing on the same neuron, causing blurring and loss of precision, opposite to the effect of lateral inhibition.

Key Takeaway:

Lateral inhibition sharpens sensory input and allows fine tactile localisation, crucial for two-point discrimination.

choices.text: Lesion of it produces astereognosis due to parietal cortex damage
First-order neuron of this tract ends in the ventroposterolateral nucleus of the thalamus
The majority of the fibres of this tract end in the somatosensory cortex
Fibres of this tract pass as the medial lemniscus through the brainstem

questions.text: Which statement about the Goll and Burdach tracts (dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway) is not true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The dorsal column-medial lemniscus (DCML) pathway, formed by the tracts of Goll (fasciculus gracilis) and Burdach (fasciculus cuneatus), carries fine touch, vibration, conscious proprioception, and pressure from the body.

Correct pathway sequence:

  • First-order neurons ascend ipsilaterally and terminate in the nucleus gracilis or nucleus cuneatus in the medulla
  • Second-order neurons decussate in the medulla as internal arcuate fibers, ascend through the medial lemniscus, and terminate in the ventroposterolateral (VPL) nucleus of the thalamus
  • Third-order neurons from the VPL project to the primary somatosensory cortex (areas 3, 1, 2)

Since first-order neurons do not end in the thalamus, Option B is the false statement.

Related Important Points:

  • Lesions in the DCML pathway cause:
    • Loss of position sense
    • Fine touch
    • Vibration
  • Astereognosis (inability to recognize objects by touch) typically occurs with parietal association cortex (areas 5, 7) damage, not direct DCML injury

Explanation of other options:

Astereognosis due to parietal cortex damage (Option A): Astereognosis occurs when the somatosensory association cortex is damaged, not the DCML tract itself.

Major projection to somatosensory cortex (Option C): Third-order thalamic neurons project to areas 3, 1, 2 in the postcentral gyrus.

Passage through medial lemniscus (Option D): Second-order fibers ascend to the thalamus via the medial lemniscus after decussating.

Key Takeaway:

The first-order neurons of the DCML tract terminate in the medulla, not the thalamus. Astereognosis results from parietal cortical lesions, not DCML tract disruption.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy born blind is learning to read using Braille script. Despite the absence of visual cues, he can effectively recognise individual characters formed by small raised dots. Which sensory property mediated by the dorsal column pathway primarily allows him to distinguish Braille characters?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Two-point discrimination in Braille reading relies on small receptive fields in the fingertips, processed via the DCML pathway, allowing precise differentiation of closely spaced dots.

  • Two-point discrimination is the ability to recognise two closely spaced points as distinct touches.
  • It is a function of fine touch processed via the dorsal column-medial lemniscus (DCML) pathway.
  • Receptive field size determines tactile acuity; smaller fields allow greater resolution.
  • Braille dots are spaced ~2.5 mm apart, within the discrimination range of human fingertips.
  • DCML also transmits vibration, proprioception, and tactile localisation, but discriminative touch is most critical in

Explanation of other options:

Tactile localisation (Option A): Tactile localisation refers to identifying the exact point of a stimulus on the skin, but it does not help differentiate between closely spaced points.

Pressure (Option B): Pressure sensation detects deep touch or sustained indentation, but lacks spatial resolution to read fine patterns like Braille.

Proprioception (Option D): Proprioception conveys information about joint position and movement, not surface touch detail.

Key Takeaway:

Two-point discrimination, mediated by the dorsal column pathway, enables blind individuals to read Braille by distinguishing raised tactile points.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient has an injury in the lateral white column of the spinal cord on the right side at the C4 segment of the spinal cord. The patient lost the sensation of pain and temperature. Which limb is probably affected in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lateral spinothalamic tract's somatotopic organisation (cervical medial, sacral/lumbar lateral) means a right-sided lateral lesion at C4 affects sacral/lumbar fibres, causing contralateral (left) lower limb sensory loss.

  • The lateral spinothalamic tract carries pain and temperature sensation.
  • These fibres cross (decussate) at the level of spinal cord entry and ascend contralaterally.
  • The tract has somatotopic organisation from medial to lateral as: cervical → thoracic → lumbar → sacral.
  • A right-sided lateral lesion at C4 affects the lateral (sacral/lumbar) fibres, thus causing loss of pain and temperature on the left lower limb.

Explanation of other options:

Right lower limb (Option B): Fibres from the right lower limb cross to the left side early and ascend there; right-sided lesions won't affect them.

Left upper limb (Option C): Fibres from the left upper limb ascend more medially, and a lateral lesion is less likely to affect them selectively.

Right upper limb (Option D): These fibres do not ascend in the right lateral column since they decussate to the left.

Key Takeaway:

A lateral spinothalamic tract lesion causes contralateral pain and temperature loss, with sacral and lumbar fibres most lateral.

choices.text: This pathway projects to the brainstem reticular formation and the limbic system, also
This pathway is responsible for the discriminative aspect of pain
This pathway mediates motivational and affective components of pain
It receives direct input from the thalamus

questions.text: In a healthy human, positron emission tomography (PET) shows activation of both primary (S1) and secondary (S2) somatosensory cortex during pain perception. Which of the following statements about the secondary somatosensory cortex (S2) is not true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The secondary somatosensory cortex (S2), located near the lateral sulcus, is involved in processing the affective and motivational components of pain. It receives input from both the primary somatosensory cortex (S1) and directly from the thalamus, and relays signals to:

  • Insular cortex
  • Anterior cingulate gyrus
  • Limbic structures

The discriminative aspect of pain (e.g., localization, intensity, quality) is primarily processed by S1, not S2. Therefore, Option B is the false statement.

Related Important Points:

  • S1 = Discriminative processing
  • S2 = Affective, emotional, and integrative roles
  • Both areas are activated during pain, but serve distinct functions

Explanation of other options:

Projects to brainstem and limbic system (Option A): S2 sends outputs to reticular formation, insula, and limbic system, mediating the emotional tone of pain.

Responsible for affective pain (Option C): S2 plays a key role in evaluating the unpleasantness and emotional response to pain.

Receives direct thalamic input (Option D): S2 receives direct projections from the thalamus, in addition to input from S1.

Key Takeaway:

S2 is not responsible for the discriminative aspect of pain; this is the function of S1. S2 integrates emotional and affective dimensions of pain, receiving input from both S1 and the thalamus.

choices.text: Failure to identify the object by sight (visual agnosia)
Failure to identify the object by touch (tactile agnosia)
Failure to identify objects by sound (auditory agnosia)

questions.text: Stereognosis is the perception of the form and nature of an object without looking at it. A 32-year-old person has lost this sensation due to injury to the cerebral cortex. Inability to identify the object is termed as agnosia. Stereognosia can be expressed by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Stereognosis is the ability to recognize objects by touch alone, relying on the integration of texture, shape, size, and weight through intact primary sensation and parietal cortical processing.

  • The condition where a person is unable to recognize objects by touch, despite normal sensation, is known as tactile agnosia, often due to a lesion in the somatosensory association cortex (areas 5 and 7).
  • Visual and auditory agnosias refer to deficits in object recognition through their respective sensory modalities, and do not cause loss of stereognosis.
  • Hence, only Option B is correct in the context of stereognosis.

Related Important Points:

  • Stereognosis is tested clinically by asking patients to identify familiar objects (e.g., coin, key) placed in their hand with eyes closed.
  • Intact dorsal column-medial lemniscus (DCML) pathway is essential for conveying touch and proprioception to the cortex, but association area damage causes agnosia despite intact sensory input.

Explanation of other options:

Visual agnosia (Option A): Inability to recognize objects by sight unrelated to stereognosis.

Auditory agnosia (Option C): Inability to recognize objects or words by sound unrelated to tactile perception.

Key Takeaway:

Stereognosis loss with intact sensation is due to tactile agnosia, caused by a lesion in the somatosensory association cortex.

choices.text: Action potential amplitude increases as the receptor potential increases
Receptor potential amplitude decreases due to adaptation
Increased stimulus strength causes higher action potential frequency and more receptor recruitment
Afferent neurons start to spontaneously depolarise with repeated pressure

questions.text: The diagram shows an afferent neuron's response to progressively increasing pressure applied to the skin using a glass probe. Despite each action potential being of uniform amplitude, the brain perceives increasing stimulus intensity. Which of the following mechanisms best explains this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Although action potentials obey the all-or-none principle, stimulus intensity is encoded by increased firing rate and activation of adjacent afferent units.

  • Receptor potentials (graded) increase with stimulus strength and cross the threshold more frequently.
  • This leads to higher action potential frequency in the same afferent (temporal coding).
  • Stronger stimuli activate nearby receptors with higher thresholds (spatial recruitment).
  • CNS interprets this combined pattern as greater sensory intensity.

Explanation of other options:

Action potential amplitude increases as the receptor potential increases (Option A): Action potential amplitude remains constant due to the all-or-none law.

Receptor potential amplitude decreases due to adaptation (Option B): Adaptation reduces receptor potential amplitude during sustained stimuli, whereas the question describes increasing stimulus intensity, which increases action potential frequency and receptor recruitment.

Afferent neurons start to spontaneously depolarise with repeated pressure (Option D): Spontaneous depolarisation is not the basis of graded intensity coding.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman presents with difficulty maintaining balance, especially in the dark. Neurological examination reveals loss of joint position sense and increased threshold for vibratory sensations in the lower limbs. MRI shows degeneration of the dorsal columns. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dorsal column degeneration with impaired proprioception and vibration sense is classically seen in subacute combined degeneration due to Vitamin B12 deficiency.

  • The posterior (dorsal) columns carry proprioceptive, fine touch, and vibration signals.
  • B12 deficiency leads to subacute combined degeneration: demyelination of the dorsal columns and corticospinal tracts.
  • Patients exhibit sensory ataxia, positive Romberg sign, and impaired vibration/joint sense.
  • Iron deficiency anaemia and chemotherapy affect peripheral nerves more commonly; HIV may cause myelopathy, but B12 deficiency is more classic in this presentation.

Explanation of other options:

Iron deficiency anaemia (Option B): Typically causes fatigue and pallor, not dorsal column degeneration.

Chemotherapy-induced neuropathy (Option C): Affects peripheral nerves; does not target spinal dorsal columns.

HIV-associated vacuolar myelopathy (Option D): May cause posterior column damage, but is less common than B12 deficiency in this context.

choices.text: Periaqueductal grey matter in the midbrain
Dorsal horn of the spinal cord

questions.text: A 49-year-old patient with oral squamous cell carcinoma is referred to the pain management clinic due to persistent, intractable pain. The patient is started on morphine, and a significant reduction in pain is observed. Which of the following structures are known sites where morphine acts to modulate pain?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Morphine exerts both supraspinal and spinal analgesic effects by acting at multiple levels of the pain pathway.

  • In the dorsal horn, morphine binds μ-opioid receptors → inhibits substance P release → suppresses nociceptive transmission. (Option C)
  • In the periaqueductal grey (PAG) and periventricular nucleus, morphine activates descending inhibitory pathways → enkephalinergic and serotonergic neurons suppress incoming pain signals at the spinal level. (Option A & B)
  • These actions explain both central and segmental inhibition of pain perception.

questions.text: A 49-year-old male named Ricky has complained of chronic cervical pain. The pain started a few years ago, probably due to overuse of a laptop with inappropriate posture. The doctor prescribed the patient medical treatment. Which of the following is not very useful in chronic neuropathic pain?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Although tramadol possesses weak μ-opioid agonist activity and serotonin/norepinephrine reuptake inhibition, which provide some benefit in neuropathic pain, it is not considered a first-line agent.

  • Chronic neuropathic pain is often linked with central sensitization, which diminishes the efficacy of classic opioids.
  • First-line therapies include:
    • Gabapentin/pregabalin - inhibit presynaptic Ca²+ channels
    • Topical capsaicin - depletes substance P from nociceptors
    • Topical lidocaine - blocks voltage-gated Na+ channels
  • Tramadol may be used in select patients unresponsive to first-line drugs, but it is not preferred initially due to side effects and addiction potential.

Explanation of other options:

Capsaicin (Option B): Topical agent that depletes substance P, useful in localized neuropathic pain.

Lidocaine (Option C): Sodium channel blocker; effective as a topical analgesic in conditions like post-herpetic neuralgia.

Gabapentin (Option D): First-line anticonvulsant drug effective in treating central and peripheral neuropathic pain via calcium channel modulation.

Key Takeaway:

Gabapentin, capsaicin, and lidocaine are preferred first-line therapies for neuropathic pain. Tramadol, although not ineffective, is used cautiously and later in treatment.

choices.text: Electrical stimulation of the periaqueductal grey matter

questions.text: A 40-year-old man sustains a soft tissue injury to his forearm. While waiting for medical help, he instinctively begins rubbing the injured area and notices temporary relief from the sharp pain. Which of the following best explains this phenomenon and has similar clinical utility?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The observed pain relief is due to the Gate Control Theory, where non-noxious input from Aβ touch fibres activates inhibitory interneurons in the dorsal horn that suppress pain transmission from Aδ and C fibres. TENS mimics this mechanism by stimulating large-diameter sensory fibres.

  • Rubbing the skin stimulates Aβ fibres, which "close the gate" in the spinal cord.
  • TENS applies low-frequency electrical stimulation (2-100 Hz) to selectively activate Aβ fibers, enhancing gate control inhibition of pain transmission in the dorsal horn.
  • This theory is the physiological basis of therapies like massage, TENS, and acupuncture.

Explanation of other options:

Topical NSAID application (Option A): Anti-inflammatory, but not related to spinal gating mechanisms.

Local opioid injection (Option C): Acts via μ-opioid receptors; not a mechanism of gate control.

Electrical stimulation of the periaqueductal grey matter (Option D): Involves supraspinal descending inhibition, not spinal gating via Aβ fibres.

Key Takeaway:

Gate control theory underlies the pain relief from touch, massage, and TENS, through Aβ-fiber activation that inhibits nociceptive transmission at the dorsal horn level.

choices.text: It is carried by A delta fibres
It is carried by the neospinothalamic tract
It is transmitted by the glutamate neurotransmitter

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with diffuse abdominal discomfort described as deep, burning. It gradually worsens over time and is not aggravated by touch. Which of the following features best distinguishes visceral pain from parietal pain?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Visceral pain is characteristically dull, burning, slow in onset, and poorly localised, owing to its transmission by slow-conducting unmyelinated C fibres that synapse in the paleospinothalamic tract.
  • Parietal pain is sharp, pricking, and well localised, transmitted via fast-conducting Aδ fibres using glutamate.

Explanation of other options:

It is carried by Aδ fibres (Option A): These carry fast parietal pain, not visceral.

It is transmitted via the neospinothalamic tract (Option C): The Neospinothalamic tract carries sharp pain, not dull visceral pain.

It uses glutamate as its primary neurotransmitter (Option D): Used by Aδ fibres, while C fibres (visceral) primarily use Substance P.

Key Takeaway:

Visceral pain is slow, poorly localised, and mediated by unmyelinated C fibres through the paleospinothalamic tract using Substance P.

choices.text: Recruitment of the lateral geniculate nucleus for auditory processing
Cortical disinhibition of visual association areas
Cross-modal plasticity leading to reassignment of the visual cortex
Enhanced projection from spinothalamic tracts to visual cortex

questions.text: A 30-year-old man, blind since birth, is evaluated for his ability to read Braille rapidly and interpret auditory signals with high accuracy. PET imaging reveals increased activity in the occipital cortex during tactile and auditory tasks. Which of the following best explains this finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cross-modal plasticity is particularly robust in congenital or early-onset blindness, as seen in this patient, allowing the occipital cortex to process tactile and auditory inputs more effectively.

  • In blind individuals, the visual cortex gets activated by auditory and tactile input, especially during Braille reading.
  • PET and fMRI studies show metabolic activity in the occipital cortex during non-visual sensory tasks.
  • This reflects reorganisation and functional reassignment, not just disinhibition or redirection of normal tracts.

Explanation of other options:

Recruitment of lateral geniculate nucleus for auditory processing (Option A): LGN is a thalamic relay for vision, not involved in auditory circuits.

Cortical disinhibition of visual association areas (Option B): Does not account for tactile/auditory processing in occipital cortex.

Enhanced projection from spinothalamic tracts to visual cortex (Option D): No direct anatomical pathway supports this.

Key Takeaway:

In sensory deprivation, cortical areas can be reassigned to intact sensory modalities, a phenomenon known as cross-modal plasticity, supported by PET evidence.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of chronic heroin use reports needing increasingly higher doses to achieve the same euphoric effect. Functional imaging reveals increased dopaminergic activity in specific brain regions associated with reward processing. Which of the following brain structures are involved in generating this drug-induced pleasure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The mesolimbic pathway (VTA to nucleus accumbens) primarily mediates pleasure and reinforcement, while the mesocortical pathway (VTA to prefrontal cortex) influences cognitive and emotional aspects of reward in addiction.

  • Addictive substances like heroin increase dopamine levels in these areas.
  • The nucleus accumbens is the core region mediating reward and
  • The VTA, located in the midbrain, contains dopamine neurons projecting to limbic and cortical areas.
  • Long-term use leads to tolerance and dopaminergic dysregulation, reinforcing compulsive drug-seeking behaviour.

Explanation of other options:

Ventral tegmental area (VTA) (Option A): Source of dopaminergic neurons in reward pathway.

Nucleus accumbens (Option B): Receives dopamine, key in mediating pleasure and reinforcement.

Mesocortical dopaminergic system (Option C): Part of the dopaminergic network linking emotion, behaviour, and cognition.

Key Takeaway:

Addiction involves activation of the mesolimbic and mesocortical dopaminergic pathways, particularly the VTA and nucleus accumbens, leading to reinforcement and pleasure.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male with a long history of alcohol dependence presents for de-addiction therapy. He reports intense craving even after abstaining for several weeks. His psychiatrist explains that the drug being prescribed acts by blocking opioid receptors in the mesolimbic system, thereby reducing the pleasurable effects of alcohol. Which of the following is the most appropriate agent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Naltrexone acts by blocking μ-opioid receptors, thereby inhibiting dopamine release in the nucleus accumbens, blunting alcohol-induced euphoria and reducing craving.
  • It is most effective in patients who drink for positive reinforcement (pleasure-driven).
  • It directly targets the reward pathway (mesolimbic dopamine system).

Explanation of other options:

Disulfiram (Option A): Causes aversive reaction when alcohol is consumed; does not reduce craving.

Acamprosate (Option C):  Helps maintain abstinence post-detox; reduces withdrawal-triggered craving.

Topiramate (Option D): Used off-label; reduces craving but not first-line.

Key Takeaway:

Naltrexone reduces alcohol craving by blocking opioid-mediated dopamine release in the brain's reward centres, and is the first-line pharmacologic agent in alcohol addiction.

questions.text: A researcher studying pain mechanisms applies intense heat and capsaicin to the skin of a subject. Which of the following nociceptive receptors is most likely to be activated by both of these stimuli?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • TRPV1 is a ligand-gated ion channel on C-fibre sensory neurons that is activated by intense heat (>43°C), acidic pH, and capsaicin.
  • It plays a key role in thermal and chemical pain transduction.
  • It allows Na+ and Ca²+ influx → depolarisation of nociceptive terminals, → pain signal.
  • Capsaicin's therapeutic effect in pain relief stems from repeated TRPV1 activation, leading to receptor desensitization and reduced nociceptive signaling over time.

Explanation of other options:

Purinergic P2X receptors (Option A): Activated by ATP; mainly mediate mechanical pain.

ASIC receptors (Option C): Detect tissue acidosis; involved in pH-triggered pain but not heat/capsaicin.

TRPM8 receptors (Option D): Respond to cold and menthol, not to heat or capsaicin.

Key Takeaway:

TRPV1 receptors are critical molecular detectors for heat and capsaicin-induced nociception and are central to thermal pain transduction.

questions.text: A neurologist tests a patients sensory perception, noting that perceived intensity rises logarithmically with stimulus strength. Which sensory coding principle is this?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Weber-Fechner law accurately describes perceived intensity for moderate stimulus ranges but may be less precise at extreme intensities, where the power law better models sensory perception in some modalities.

  • Formula: Perceived sensation ∝ log (stimulus intensity)
  • Useful in vision, hearing, and somatosensation, where signal compression is essential for interpretation.

Explanation of other options:

Power law (Option A): States that perceived intensity is proportional to a power of stimulus strength; more accurate for some modalities but not logarithmic.

Law of projection (Option B): Refers to localisation of sensation to the point of receptor stimulation, regardless of the pathway.

Law of specific nerve energies (Option D): Each sensory nerve transmits only one type of sensation, regardless of how it is stimulated.

choices.text: Receptor with a large receptive field

questions.text: The spike trains in the figure represent action potentials elicited by a mechanical stimulus from a probe applied to a cutaneous receptor. The trace marked by the arrow shows a burst of action potentials only at the onset of the stimulus, despite continuous pressure. Which of the following is the most likely receptor type involved?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The arrowed spike train represents a receptor that responds only at the onset of stimulus, characteristic of rapidly adapting receptors (phasic).

  • Meissner corpuscles are rapidly adapting mechanoreceptors located in glabrous skin.
  • They respond to light touch and low-frequency vibration, firing only briefly upon stimulus application.
  • This adaptation allows detection of dynamic changes rather than sustained pressure.

Explanation of other options:

Option D: Receptor with large receptive field - Not relevant to the adaptation rate; spike pattern depends on receptor type, not field size.

Key Takeaway:

Meissner corpuscles rapidly adapt and fire only at stimulus onset, making them ideal for detecting touch onset and motion across skin.

choices.text: They are receptors for warm temperatures
These receptors are activated by Menthol
Their firing rate is maximum at 40 °C

questions.text: True about TRPM8 receptors
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In TRPM8, receptors are stimulated by menthol, which is found in mint. Mint ingestion gives a cooling effect.

Cold Temperature Receptors:

  • TRPM8 receptors are cold temperature receptors. (Option A)
  • Cold receptors are inactive at temperatures of 40°C, but then steadily increase their firing rate as skin temperature falls to about 24°C. (Option C)
  • From 24°C as the temperature decreases, the firing rate of cold receptors decreases until the temperature reaches 10°C. Below that temperature, they are inactive and cold, which makes them an effective local anaesthetic. (Option D)

Warm Temperature Receptors:

  • Warm temperature receptors are TRPV3 and
  • TRPV3 and TRPV4 receptors on sensory nerve endings are activated when skin temperatures reach 33-39°C and 25-34°C, respectively. The firing rate of warm receptors can further increase as the skin temperature reaches about 45°C; they become silent if skin temperature is further increased to induce a sensation of pain.

Key Takeaway:

  • TRPM8 receptors are cold temperature receptors.
  • TRPV3 and TRPV4 are Warm temperature receptors.

questions.text: Receptors can be classified in many ways. One classification classifies it into tonic and phasic receptors. True about the tonic receptor is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tonic receptors are slowly adapting sensory receptors that continue to fire throughout a sustained stimulus. This property allows the body to:

  • Continuously monitor the presence and duration of a stimulus
  • Provide constant sensory input as long as the stimulus persists

Key characteristics of tonic receptors:

  • Slowly adapting
  • Constant firing rate with sustained stimulus
  • Examples: Merkel discs, Ruffini endings
  • Encode stimulus duration and partial stimulus intensity

In contrast, phasic receptors like Pacinian corpuscles and Meissner's corpuscles adapt quickly and primarily detect changes (onset/offset) of a stimulus.

Related Important Points:

Explanation of other options:

Rapid adaptation (Option A): Applies to phasic receptors, not tonic ones.

Pacinian corpuscles (Option B): Are phasic, rapidly adapting receptors, not tonic.

Intensity encoding (Option D): Both tonic and phasic receptors can encode intensity via firing frequency, but tonic receptors are defined by sustained response, not intensity alone.

Key Takeaway:

Tonic receptors respond continuously during a sustained stimulus, allowing for perception of duration and ongoing sensation.

questions.text: Match the following mechanoreceptors with their primary function:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Merkel cells are expanded dendritic endings in the epidermis of glabrous skin that respond to sustained pressure and
  • Meissner corpuscles are dendrites encapsulated in connective tissue beneath the epidermis of glabrous (non-hairy) skin and respond to slow vibration.
  • Pacinian corpuscles are the largest cutaneous mechanoreceptors in the dermis of glabrous and hairy skin. They are comprised of a nerve ending encapsulated by concentric layers of connective tissue. They respond to fast vibration and deep pressure.
  • Ruffini corpuscles are enlarged dendritic endings with elongated capsules in the dermis of glabrous and hairy skin; they respond to stretch and fluttering vibration.

Key Takeaway:

Merkel - Sustained pressure

Meissner - Slow vibration

Pacinian - Deep pressure

Ruffini - Fluttering vibration

questions.text:
Which of the following receptors are stimulated by mechanical stimuli?
1. Pacinian corpuscles
2. Cochlear hair cells
3. Pruriceptors
4. Muscle spindle
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Purinceptors are activated by chemical mediators like histamine and prostaglandins, distinguishing them from mechanoreceptors like Pacinian corpuscles, cochlear hair cells, and muscle spindles, which respond to mechanical deformation.

  • Pacinian corpuscles are classic rapidly adapting mechanoreceptors that respond to vibration and deep pressure.
  • Cochlear hair cells transduce sound-induced mechanical vibration into neural signals through the displacement of stereocilia.
  • Muscle spindles detect changes in muscle length and are mechanoreceptors critical for proprioception.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old male presents with sudden, severe, stabbing pain confined to the right side of his face. The episodes last for a few seconds, recur frequently throughout the day, and are triggered by a light touch over the cheek or while chewing. He is otherwise neurologically intact. Which of the following statements is/are true regarding this condition?
1. It is due to the involvement of the trigeminal nerve
2. The pain is typically lancinating or electric shock-like in character
3. It is triggered by mechanoreceptive stimuli such as touch or swallowing
4. It is associated with widespread motor weakness of facial muscles
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tic douloureux refers to trigeminal neuralgia, presenting as paroxysmal, sharp facial pain triggered by mild mechanical stimuli.

  • Trigeminal neuralgia (tic douloureux) affects the sensory distribution of CN V or CN IX, producing severe, sudden pain. (Statement 1)
  • Pain is described as lancinating or stabbing, often likened to an electric shock. (Statement 2)
  • Triggered by mechanical stimuli, such as even mild touch, shaving, brushing teeth, or swallowing. (Statement 3)
  • There is no motor weakness in most cases; cranial motor functions remain unaffected between attacks. (Statement 4)

Key Takeaway:
Tic douloureux (trigeminal neuralgia) is characterised by paroxysmal, lancinating facial pain triggered by light touch or movement, with no motor deficits.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man presents for evaluation of persistent dry eyes and dry mouth. On neurological assessment, there is reduced tear production and decreased parotid gland activity. These findings suggest dysfunction of parasympathetic fibres from which of the following cranial nerves?
1. Facial nerve (CN VII)
2. Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)
3. Vagus nerve (CN X)
4. Oculomotor nerve (CN III)
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dry eyes and dry mouth point to impaired parasympathetic innervation of the lacrimal glands, submandibular/sublingual glands, and parotid glands:

  • Facial nerve (CN VII):
    • Parasympathetic fibres to the lacrimal gland (via pterygopalatine ganglion).
    • Innervates the submandibular and sublingual glands via the submandibular ganglion.
  • Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX):
    • Provides parasympathetic input to the parotid gland via the otic ganglion.
  • Vagus nerve (CN X):
    • Supplies thoracic and abdominal viscera, not involved in lacrimal or salivary gland function.
  • Oculomotor nerve (CN III):
    • Innervates the pupillary sphincter and ciliary muscle; no role in tear or saliva production.

Hence, only CN VII and CN IX are relevant to the symptoms of xerophthalmia and xerostomia.
